For the first question on the split of growth markets and emerging market and mature markets, I think it's a result of – of course, our starting point is it was growing over the years. I think we started this something like 20%, 26% or so common revenue share when we came together with BOC, so that's a very strong growth. Is there a target behind that? Answer there is, really, of course, because of growth in population and structure of the market and higher gas density per inhabitant, that's driving the growth in the emerging market based on our very strong market share positions.

That's one part but – and now the but is important – when we talk about other opportunities, when we talk about energy projects, this is not excluded in emerging markets and we have a very nice slide in the presentation about the growth opportunities in the market on page 11 of the presentation. I think this gives you the guidance. So it would be clear that we take all opportunities wherever they arise and with this trend of a faster growth in the emerging market, then, of course, you will see an continuation of growth in proportion to mature markets but no target.

The second question, I think, is related to operational issues in these markets from an perspective of tax loss carry forward and I think we have to come back to you on that issue, I don't have that available for you, it's rather too small. I wouldn't make an issue out of that.
Okay, thanks a lot.
Our next question comes from the line of Sebastian Bap (01:49:44). Please go ahead with your question.

Yeah, thanks very much. I just have a one quick question. I was quite supposed to see sequential growth in operating profit in Asia in the fourth quarter, given the weakness we've seen in the Chinese steel industry, I know that Asia is bit more than China but I would assume that Chinese steel actually is quite an important segment for you. Could you just elaborate, please, what you're seeing in that segment at the moment and what you're seeing in the fourth quarter? And what was really behind that growth and operating profit? Was it mostly the pricing impact you elaborated on or what actually drove that sequential profit? Thank you.

Yeah, thank you for your question. I think it is, as you said, it was related to some pricing issues in that market. I think on the first quarter, it would be now really too early to dig down into the first quarter development. In the middle of the first quarter, of course, the first – you know the development overall, it was Chinese New Year in the first two months, all of that is included and would be now not wise to talk about that at that moment in time.
And if you could just comment on the impact from the steel industry on your business?

No, I think there is nothing special to report on, honestly. I think we have seen what we expected and I cannot comment on that because we have not the quarter one call at this moment in time, I think, and here is nothing special to mention at that point in time. I think we have, as you know, we have built our strategy in China on the big players at that moment in time and we were not moving into the, let's say, third-tier – second-tier business. We have moved in recently but this is not coming on stream at that moment in time. So I think we are rather with the consolidators than which the ones who will be consolidated.
Thank you.
Our next question comes from the line of Annette Weaver (01:51:55). Please go ahead with your question.

Good afternoon. Ann Weaver from BHS Bank (01:51:59). A quick kind of housekeeping question on the D&A in Gases in Q4. It's risen compared to the run rate in the preceding quarters, and I think there is an impairment of €26 million in the full year in the D&A charge. We have seen the €50 million for FX in Q2, so what is the rest about in Q4, presumably in Q4? Thanks.
I think there's nothing special to report about, honestly, in the change, nothing special. No South African issue or something like that, I mean nothing special.
But there must have been an impairment in Q4, right? I mean the €11 million?
Yes, that is the one-time which we have seen, yeah.
Okay.
We indeed have no further questions at this time so I'll hand the conference back to you.
So thank you very much and we are looking forward to have follow-up discussions with you in quarter one and you are, of course, invited to our Annual Shareholder Meeting, which is on the same day.
Thank you very much for the participation and lively discussion. Have a good day.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your participation. This concludes today's conference. You may now disconnect your line. Thank you.
